history.content: If you are into devices/circuits, classes in solid state physics might be helpful (Physics 141A/ Physics 240A) or even statistical mechanics (Physics 112/ grad level equivalent). The MSE department also has some materials characterization classes (MSE 104/204) that could be useful or even some thin film classes (MSE 225). I am not so sure about the signals side of EE.

children.subject: idk how much you like probability but Stat 200A might be a good option if you want to get better at it and only took 70; Stat 201AB is also there if you have a more concrete probability background (i.e. have taken Stat 134 or EECS 126). Ofc Physics 137AB is a fairly useful series if you haven't taken those classes, especially if you're doing device research.

Math 104 and 105, the physics and stats courses mentioned here by others, maybe some IEOR courses in optimization or process control, a course on the history or ethics of science, a mechanical engineering course on MEMs or robotics, a civil engineering course on cyber physical systems or the majority of material science courses are all good options for someone in your position

history.content:
Hi everyone, I'll be a 5th year M.S. student this next year, and we're required to take 2 non-eecs upper division or grad courses for graduation. I still need one more to take but I'm having a hard time thinking of what I should do. I'd like it to be valuable and not just an easy class to meet the requirement. 

For reference I am pretty heavily on the EE side, and will probably want something more math-y or physics-y

Any suggestions? Preferably in Fall.
history.subject: Non-EECS Electives for 5th Year M.S.?
